On Wed, 24 Nov 2004 00:46:17 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> Derek, you said before that currently not all fingerprint
> classification is done by machine.  Is there a particular step in
> the process that the roving eye can fill?  For example, is the
> experiment you are doing now a task usually done by human eye?
> It seems even if the entire process of fingerprint identification
> can't be done with the roving eye, it may still be able to fill some
> crucial link in the chain.

It might be useful to distinguish between the three subdomains that
all fall under fingerprint recognition:

1) Fingerprint Classification -- The process of determining which
class a fingerprint belongs to.  The Henry Classification System
divides prints into 3 broad classes (whorl, loop, and arch).  Those
can be subdivided into more specific classes (left/right loop,
arch/tented arch).  Left/right loop are sometimes called radial/ulnar
loop.  And sometimes those classifications are even more granular
(e.g., a whorl can be two swirled loops or concentric circles).  This
type of classification is used primarily to divide a fingerprint
database into bins, to reduce the time spent doing 1-to-many searches
by reducing the amount of the database to search.

2) Fingerprint Identification (1-to-many) -- The process of checking a
single unknown print against a database of prints for a match. 
Usually for law enforcement purposes, either trying to match a latent
print from a crime scene to a matching print in a database.

3) Fingerprint Verification (1-to1) -- The process of verifying a
single print against a template, usually used for security purposes. 
If your laptop is fingerprint locked, when someone puts their finger
on the pad, the software checks the scanned print against the stored
template and either grants or denies access based on the match
confidence.

So for commercial systems, obviously verification is fully automated,
though my impression is that in fingerprint identification systems
there is still some human intervention.  I honestly am not that
familiar with the industry to know to what extent various systems are
automated, and how much they still rely on human expertise and
training.  The recently deployed US VISIT program
(http://www.dhs.gov/dhspublic/interapp/content_multi_image/content_multi_image_0006.xml),
our new immigration system, apparently is set up to store the two
index fingerprints (and a digital face photo) of every non-immigrant
entering the country.  I honestly don't know what the ratio of human
intervention vs. automation is involved in how they store and search
their database.

So obviously we need to do a bit more research on the
commercial/governmental side of things.  I don't know to what extent
the academic and commercial communities interact and share ideas, but
so far I've been primarily reading the academic literature.  I don't
know if there are any people on this list that are interested in
biometric applications (if there are, speak up). :)

This just seemed like an interesting, real-world problem where there
is a good amount of previous research to compare results to.  Whether
or not there is a direct commercial application for fingerprint
classification, I really don't know.  There definitely would be for
identification and verification, though competition is extremely
tough...there are already a number of very good algorithms being sold.
 If a roving eye/neural net approach can improve upon speed and
compactness (I don't think it could improve much on accuracy, which is
already very high), then it might be able to compete with commercial
products.

But we haven't even begun to look at applying this approach to either
identification and verification, which may be more difficult than
classification.

Derek
